ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Physical Organic Chemistry mechanisms, techniques, and literature.
I developed a sense of how to look at reactions in a physical sense, how the molecules fit together and what makes reactions go

I developed an awareness for the interesting aspects of physical organic chemistry which I will likely encounter during my time as a researcher in the field of chemistry. Professor Miller emphasized studying the big effects and brought primary literature in as evidentiary material for the relevance and importance of topics in physical organic chemistry.
I relearned how to think about how and why multiple processes and reactions in organic chemistry occur as seen through MO theory, host-guest interactions, and strain energy.
Great course. I learned a lot about how to think and about phys org in general.
This course allows me to explore a variety of concepts in the realm of physical organic chemistry. It also helps me develop my skills of reading primary literatures as many of them as presented.
This was a fantastic course in physical organic chemistry. In a clear and organized way, Professor Miller guided us through the field by analyzing some of the crucial papers of the last decades.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Final exam didn't test on a lot of content that seemed relevant to the course, such as Kinetic Isotope effects, Linear free energy relationships, FMO analysis of pericyclic reactions (Diels alder, electrocyclic reactions, carbene reactions, migratory shifts). Instead it tested on some more obscure topics that didn't seem as relevant, such as Native Chemical Ligation, choosing whether a hexaphenyl ethane would exist as a diradical, and light induced isomerization (which didn't seem to be covered at all in the radical chemistry lecture at all). I think challenging exams are fine, as long as the topics tested on are given reasonable exposure to the students. It seemed that the exam had too many concepts that weren't well covered or didn't have any practice problems to help prepare for the questions.
This class has a lot of interesting material, i think lecture could get a bit hard to focus on with the explanations of papers made it hard to connect with the lecture material
Kept to topics which I found to be very relevant. Sometimes slides were a little overwhelming.

I think this class provides a lot of great concepts that are relevant to all organic chemists and the use of real-world examples helped me see how physical organic concepts are applied. I wish that there were more practice problems during class as that would help me see how I can apply topics.
Lot of notes. sometimes wanted more core concepts but overall great class.
It is a wonderful course.

I greatly appreciated learning about physical organic chemistry concepts though exposure to the primary literature from different fields of chemistry. Another strength of this course is Professor Miller's enthusiasm for the field and for teaching. I also enjoyed the weekly/biweekly problem sets that allowed me to consolidate the knowledge gained in class.
Very interesting material, although a bit difficult at times (which isn't exactly bad)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The course had a lot of amazing concepts and the workload is reasonable. Furthermore, the instructor is absolutely amazing at explaining concepts and expressing his enthusiasm for the subject.
Yes, I think it was interesting and fun to learn

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in understanding why many organic reactions are favorable/acceptable and really anyone interested in the intersection between organic chemistry and biology. Prof. Miller introduces a lot of examples at the intersection of organic chemistry and biological processes and the MO theory explanation of multiple processes (like pericyclic reactions) aided in my understanding of why some reactions are allowed or prohibited.
Yes, I learned a lot.
Yes, since this course is eye-opening and allows one to be exposed to many novel studies.
Yes, absolutely! The interdisciplinarity of this course makes it perfect for students from all fields of chemistry.
Yes, a very fun course
